content.raw:
With f551462 line coverage is at practically 100%.

The only "uncovered" lines are [this assert](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-physics/pull-requests/4/part-1-compositedata-implementation-and/diff#Lsrc/CompositeData.ccT308) which is impossible to cover without an implementation bug, and [this class declaration](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-physics/pull-requests/4/part-1-compositedata-implementation-and/diff#Lsrc/utils/TestDataTypes.hhT50), which I have no idea what it even means for that line to not be covered.

Since that commit is only adding tests, I assume that everyone's approvals will still stand. I'll merge this PR in a few hours if no one raises an objection.

content.raw:
`QueryMode` has been changed to an enum class: f386d01

I also renamed `QUERY_NORMAL` to `NORMAL` and `QUERY_SILENT` to `SILENT` since those now always have to be prefixed by `QueryMode::`, and needing to always have "Query" in there twice seemed redundant. I can change those names back if you prefer.
content.html:
QueryMode has been changed to an enum class: f386d01

I also renamed QUERY_NORMAL to NORMAL and QUERY_SILENT to SILENT since those now always have to be prefixed by QueryMode::, and needing to always have "Query" in there twice seemed redundant. I can change those names back if you prefer.

content.html:
I thought codecov was useful until we added support for branch coverage:

  • #!/ignitionrobotics/ign-cmake/issues/28/branch-coverage-results-hard-to-interpret

I'll make a pull request to revert it so we can discuss further

content.raw:
I've stopped looking at the `codecov` app. The results from codecov seem to consistently fail, regardless of whether coverage has increased or not. Instead, I run code coverage locally.

1. `cmake -DCMAKE_BUILD_TYPE=Coverage; make -j8`
2. `make test`
3. `make coverage`
4. `firefox coverage/index.html`

A specific target coverage percentage is difficult to prescribe. Line coverage over 80% is good, over 90% is fantastic, and 100% can be achievable for some files and very difficult for others. In general, it depends on the file.

I use the code coverage to identify where tests are needed.
content.html:
I've stopped looking at the codecov app. The results from codecov seem to consistently fail, regardless of whether coverage has increased or not. Instead, I run code coverage locally.

  1. cmake -DCMAKE_BUILD_TYPE=Coverage; make -j8
  2. make test
  3. make coverage
  4. firefox coverage/index.html

A specific target coverage percentage is difficult to prescribe. Line coverage over 80% is good, over 90% is fantastic, and 100% can be achievable for some files and very difficult for others. In general, it depends on the file.

I use the code coverage to identify where tests are needed.

yeah, it's confusing to me too:

content.raw: The thing is, there isn't any branching in the `Cloneable` or `MakeCloneable` classes, and there's very little branching in `CompositeData`, besides the `Copy` function. There are a lot of yellow-colored lines in `CompositeData` which don't involve any branching, so I don't understand what it would be complaining about.
content.html: The thing is, there isn't any branching in the Cloneable or MakeCloneable classes, and there's very little branching in CompositeData, besides the Copy function. There are a lot of yellow-colored lines in CompositeData which don't involve any branching, so I don't understand what it would be complaining about.

content.raw: I think the functions may be covered, but there might not be 100% line or branch coverage
content.html: I think the functions may be covered, but there might not be 100% line or branch coverage

content.raw:
I think I have a better idea of what's being reported.

codecov seems to be splitting its reporting between the header files. `Cloneable.hh` is being reported at 33%, but [`detail/Cloneable.hh` is reporting 92.31%](https://codecov.io/bb/ignitionrobotics/ign-physics/src/d5ed8493562a3b02c6fbab077c92abb538d876d1/include/ignition/physics/detail/Cloneable.hh).

I still kind of think this is silly, because I guarantee that 100% of both headers are being covered by tests, but I guess we can only expect the tool to be an estimate.
content.html:
I think I have a better idea of what's being reported.

codecov seems to be splitting its reporting between the header files. Cloneable.hh is being reported at 33%, but detail/Cloneable.hh is reporting 92.31%.

I still kind of think this is silly, because I guarantee that 100% of both headers are being covered by tests, but I guess we can only expect the tool to be an estimate.

content.raw:
It's worth noting that the coverage checker is only highlighting three lines:

1. The constructor of `Cloneable`
2. The destructor of `Cloneable`
3. The class name of `MakeCloneable`.

I'm pretty clueless about what exactly the coverage checker thinks it's reporting.
content.html:
It's worth noting that the coverage checker is only highlighting three lines:

  1. The constructor of Cloneable
  2. The destructor of Cloneable
  3. The class name of MakeCloneable.

I'm pretty clueless about what exactly the coverage checker thinks it's reporting.

content.raw:
I added a comprehensive set of unit tests for `Cloneable` and `MakeCloneable` here: d5ed849

But [line coverage for Cloneable.hh](https://codecov.io/bb/ignitionrobotics/ign-physics/src/d5ed8493562a3b02c6fbab077c92abb538d876d1/include/ignition/physics/Cloneable.hh) is still being reported as only 33%.

I'm not sure what it would take to satisfy the coverage checker at this point.
content.html:
I added a comprehensive set of unit tests for Cloneable and MakeCloneable here: d5ed849

But line coverage for Cloneable.hh is still being reported as only 33%.

I'm not sure what it would take to satisfy the coverage checker at this point.

content.raw:
I noticed while looking at bc4ada0 that the implementations of `Insert` and `InsertOrAssign` are nearly the same, with the exception of this `else` block in `InsertOrAssign`.

Is there an advantage of trying to move this logic to a private function that `Insert` and `InsertOrAssign` would both call? It would be tricky since there are already variable arguments involved. If it's not worth it, feel free to say no.
content.html:
I noticed while looking at bc4ada0 that the implementations of Insert and InsertOrAssign are nearly the same, with the exception of this else block in InsertOrAssign.

Is there an advantage of trying to move this logic to a private function that Insert and InsertOrAssign would both call? It would be tricky since there are already variable arguments involved. If it's not worth it, feel free to say no.

update.description: This pull request is a spin-off of pull request #1. This only includes the implementation of the generic CompositeData class, without any of the data specification or template metaprogramming.
update.title: Part 1: CompositeData implementation and tests

content.raw: After implementing `InsertOrAssign(~)`, I realized that there's no real advantage to also having `InsertOrReplace(~)`. We already require that all `Data` types in the `CompositeData` are copyable, so we can always use the assignment operator on them. `InsertOrReplace(~)` doesn't generally accomplish anything that can't be done more efficiently and more safely by `InsertOrAssign(~)`, and if someone *really* wants to delete and replace an existing data entry, they can always call `composite.Remove<Data>()` followed by `composite.Insert<Data>(~)`.
content.html: After implementing InsertOrAssign(~), I realized that there's no real advantage to also having InsertOrReplace(~). We already require that all Data types in the CompositeData are copyable, so we can always use the assignment operator on them. InsertOrReplace(~) doesn't generally accomplish anything that can't be done more efficiently and more safely by InsertOrAssign(~), and if someone really wants to delete and replace an existing data entry, they can always call composite.Remove<Data>() followed by composite.Insert<Data>(~).

content.raw:
Per our meeting, the API has been streamlined by bc4ada0 and b26a67f.

The essential changes are that `GetOrCreate<T>(~)` has been replaced by `Insert<T>(~)`, and `Create<T>(~)` has been replaced by `InsertOrAssign<T>(~)`. Both `Insert<Data>(~)` and `InsertOrAssign<Data>(~)` return an `InsertResult<Data>` which contains two fields: (1) a reference to the data entry in the `CompositeData`, and (2) a `bool` which is true if an entry was inserted (meaning the entry did not exist before the function call) or false if an entry already existed.

Additionally, `Has<T>()` and `StatusOf<T>()` do not accept a `QueryMode` option; they will simply never affect the query flag.

Next I'll be going through and cleaning up the documentation throughout the source code.
content.html:
Per our meeting, the API has been streamlined by bc4ada0 and b26a67f.

The essential changes are that GetOrCreate<T>(~) has been replaced by Insert<T>(~), and Create<T>(~) has been replaced by InsertOrAssign<T>(~). Both Insert<Data>(~) and InsertOrAssign<Data>(~) return an InsertResult<Data> which contains two fields: (1) a reference to the data entry in the CompositeData, and (2) a bool which is true if an entry was inserted (meaning the entry did not exist before the function call) or false if an entry already existed.

Additionally, Has<T>() and StatusOf<T>() do not accept a QueryMode option; they will simply never affect the query flag.

Next I'll be going through and cleaning up the documentation throughout the source code.

content.raw: Changed: bc4ada0
content.html: Changed: bc4ada0

content.raw: ok
content.html: ok

content.raw:
In the current implementation of this function, it always uses the type's constructor, never the assignment operator.

We could name this function something like `InsertOrReplace<T>(Args&&...)` and then add a function called `InsertOrAssign<T>(const T&)` where the latter can *only* be given a const-reference to an existing object of type `T`, and then it will use the assignment operator (which might be more efficient than constructing a new object in some cases).
content.html:
In the current implementation of this function, it always uses the type's constructor, never the assignment operator.

We could name this function something like InsertOrReplace<T>(Args&&...) and then add a function called InsertOrAssign<T>(const T&) where the latter can only be given a const-reference to an existing object of type T, and then it will use the assignment operator (which might be more efficient than constructing a new object in some cases).
